qas.question: Halford Mackinder and Friedrich Ratzel where what kind of geographers?
Friedrich Ratzel thought imperialism was what for the country?
How would the geographical societies in Europe support certain travelers?

answers.text: fund travelers who would come back with tales of their discoveries

qas.question: Halford Mackinder and Friedrich Ratzel where what kind of philosophers?
Friedrich Ratzel thought imperialism was not what for the country?
How would the geographical societies in Europe reject certain travelers?

context: The Royal Geographical Society of London and other <a3_0><b8_0>geographical societies in Europe<b8_0/><a3_0/> had great influence and were <a4_3>able to <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><a4_4><b9_0>fund<a4_4/><a4_0/> travelers<b9_0/><a4_3/><a4_2/> who would come back with tales of their discoveries<a4_1/>. These societies also served as a space for travellers to share these stories.<a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4><b7_0>Political<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> geographers such as Friedrich Ratzel of <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4><b5_0>Germany<b5_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> and Halford Mackinder of <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4><b6_0>Britain<b6_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> also supported imperialism. Ratzel believed expansion was <a3_1><a3_3><a3_4>necessary<a3_4/><a3_3/> for a state’s <a3_2>survival<a3_2/><a3_1/> while Mackinder supported Britain’s imperial expansion; these two arguments dominated the discipline for decades.
